Award.AwardTitle: Science Masters Program: Connecting NanoScience to MicroSystems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).
This is a new 18-month Science Master's degree in NanoScience and MicroSystems. The program curriculum is providing students with the knowledge and skill to turn breakthroughs in nanoscience into innovative commercial technology. It uses project-based learning as a method for integrating education, research, and training in nanotechnology. It targets the needs of employers by preparing graduates for careers in nanotechnology with local and national start-up companies and established firms.

Through a partnership with the Management of Technology program located within University of New Mexico's Anderson School of Management, students are learning skills in finance, marketing, communication, and project management needed to bring new technology to the marketplace. Entrepreneurship is developed through cohort-based participation in the University of New Mexico's Business Plan Competition.

Broader Impact: Nanoscience is an important base of support for key industries in the 21st century. New Mexico is recognized as a center of nanotechnology research and entrepreneurship. The University of New Mexico is Hispanic-Serving and classified by the Carnegie Foundation as a research university with very high research activity. Competitively awarded stipends will be available to the first two student cohorts, helping to ensure broad access to this degree. Internships and research experiences will be tied to the needs of local and national industry and government labs. Upon completion of this degree program, students will be prepared for careers and leadership positions in nanotechnology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: We implemented a non-thesis MS graduate curriculum that introduced 33 students to the "Innovation Ecosystem" as it exists in the State of New Mexico. NSF project funds provided financial support for 21 of the students and supported adminstrative costs associated with the broadened curriculum. The scientific component was based on the highly interdisciplinary Nanoscience and Microsystems graduate degree program while the innovation component drew from a combination of specialized courses in the Management of Technology program and capstone participation in UNM's Technology Business Plan Competition (TBPC).

A cohort strategy was used to improve the students' learning experience in classes, laboratories and seminars and the students were encouraged to form teams for the TBPC. Over the three-year duration of this project, students won two first-place and three third-place awards from the TBPC. By moving innovation to the fore, students became familiar with the Innovation Ecosystem earlier in their careers than a traditional science and engineering MS program would have provided. 

Broader Impact: An existing MS program was significantly enriched by including broadening experiences that improved communication skills and increased students' familiarity with all facets of the innovation ecosystem. A total of 33 students successfully completed the program and therefore, the careers of all 33 were enhanced as our objectives defined. As concern that underrepresented groups are doubly underrepresented in technology commercialization and entrepreneurship grows, this project graduated two Native Americans, five Hispanics, one African American and 12 women. Therefore, students from a wide range of backgrounds and experiences are now better prepared to be entrepreneurs and innovators.

Public outreach occurred in partnership with Musuems in the Albuquerque area. One specific result was co-sponsorship of a "Science on Tap" informal science education series hosted by a local restaurant.
